div.p: [Applause]
good evening it is so awesome to be here
so I am Brenna Berman as I said and I
was the CIO for the city of Chicago for
so I was CIO for four years I was first
deputy CIO which is nearly CIO doing
actually more work than the CIO for here
before that and I was deputy budget
director for the first year that mayor
Emanuel was an office before that so
that's six years with the city of
Chicago which if you know about anything
about working in the city like Tom does
or Jean and Nick do it's like dog years
so I'm ready to retire which I did at
the end of March at least from working
in the city I tried to take many months
off and my husband said four weeks and
then we need a paycheck back so I took
four weeks I want to take about 15
minutes and actually talk a little bit
about to be honest not what I got done
you know six years but what frankly my
amazing team got done because my main
job was dealing with frankly mostly
legal and keeping the mayor away from my
team and but there was actually quite a
bit that changed in in those six years
with how technology in the city works
and part of why I'm excited to have this
conversation here on a Tuesday night is
because many of you and many of the
folks who may not be here but are often
here we're partners in that work so this
is like the perfect place to have that
conversation because I think you
understand it and we're part of that
journey so a couple things that that I
want to share and then maybe a couple
questions if there are any so so
Chicago's first tech plan really created
this collective vision and some of you
may actually know about that tech plan
but even if you don't it was the first
time that the city of Chicago actually
stepped back and said you know what what
can technology do for the city of
Chicago and it talked about a lot of
things that had nothing to do with city
government it talked about
you know growing growing the tech space
as economic development rights startups
and bringing large tech companies
downtown it talked about technology
infrastructure like broadband still lots
of work to do there it talked about
technology and education and STEM
investment but it also talked about
effective government and how technology
can change how city government gets
things done and that's essentially what
we focused on for five years and how we
could really give technology a seat at
the table in the mayor's office to
change how government how Cercado city
government was doing things and there
were some significant changes in how
that worked in a couple of specific ways
and the first one and I know you I think
you hear a lot about this and some of
you have helped us work on these
specific projects or use some of the
open data that's now available but a lot
some of this or one of the big ways was
around how data and analytics are now
core decision-making tools across
departments and you've got a couple
the open data portal on the bottom right
there's a new version of that out there
recently if you haven't seen it you
should go check it out there's there's
new ways to access data and by the way
we've this I still say we cuz I haven't
been gone that long but city departments
use open data internally as much as as
outsiders do so this was as much an
improvement for City departments as it
was for the public who accesses the data
or companies who use the API and I can
point to this change the other day in my
new job I needed to know what someone
was paid and literally like went to go
to the city data portal click oh wait I
don't have everybody's salary online
anymore like I did at the city so what
you're seeing up here is some examples
like open grid right which puts all of
our spatial data onto a map so people
can see it and actually see where things
are being delivered in the city you're
seeing one example of predictive
analytics right that's a comparison of
critical restaurant violations right the
data-driven decision making against the
status quo my one of my favorite
projects right the array of things which
is still ongoing which I still get to be
involved in
data coming online soon what a project
that took what five years to actually
bring into reality which will continue
to change the landscape of data in the
city as it collected and we share that
publicly but the biggest change here
right so these trends are going on in in
other cities as well right open data is
almost an expectation in many cities but
here's actually what's changed in
Chicago

p.span: any time the mayor's office or a

div.p: department has a business initiative
right no matter what it is part of that
this decision what data do we have and
and to figure that out they make a call
to Tom or there's a question of okay
well we're going to make a big press
announcement about some initiative it's
well what are the data sets that we need
to add to the data portal to support
this discussion in the public about
whatever that initiative is a good
example around this is the whole
discussion that happened a little more
than a year ago around around bad
landlords and problem building right so
the building department in the law
talk about how the city strengthened the
tools that they had sort of punish and
call out bad landlord ones who weren't
taking care of their apartments and who
were frankly putting their renters at
risk in dangerous apartments and one of
the things that they did was worked with
the Department of innovation in
technology around the data sets and the
analysis they could do to identify those
landlords to be more proactive in
working with them and that was actually
that's a real change and now that's
actually like the status quo in the
process of how the city develops new
initiatives so now there's actually this
real approach around data-driven
policymaking in the city of Chicago that
wasn't there five years ago
the second thing was actually this real
initiative that certainly there were
announcements around about you know
going paperless which I love what people
do know well how much money are you
saving on paper I don't care about the
papers is that expensive this isn't
about the paper it's actually about
getting these transactions online and
looking at the processes and seeing how
you make them more efficient and
effective for the people that no longer
need to come in and stand in line
to talk to someone and those
efficiencies are two part right it's
about the resident or the business owner
who's not standing in line at City Hall
or some older manic office anymore to
buy a permit or get a business plan it's
also about the internal efficiencies for
the city worker who's no longer updating
an address for the person who stood in
line to come in and update their address
because that's not a high value service
they've now we've now freed up five or
ten minutes for each address update
because that's about the estimate and
when you add those together right so six
address updates is an hour
imagine what that city worker can get
done with that free hour doing some
other high-value piece of work right so
this is about efficiency in city
processes not about yes it's all good to
save paper but it's not about that it's
about actually changing those city
processes and by the by the beginning of
2016 or the middle of 2016
this sort of paperless approach had had
actually been achieved for both city
permits city licenses which is all of C

p.span: B acp a couple of other

div.p: departments thrown in there and actually
across the procurement process so think
about that one for a minute which most
people didn't realize was part of this
that's the city's internal contracting
process and the external bid process
which is actually now done completely
online and if any of you would come
before this and walk through the city's
procurement office you literally would
have seen box after box after box of
paper contract now which is all managed
online which is a huge efficiency for
the parties involved in those processes
both internally and externally which is
a big change in how people view those
processes and then there's the one that
is frequent pretty close to my heart
partially because it it doesn't get the
press release because nobody sees these
and for those of you that are actually
in core operational tech I think you'll
share this with me and these are the
ones that are operational sustainability
projects that nobody ever knows you're

p.span: doing they're hard to get done because

div.p: the it's not that the mayor's office
doesn't care is that they frankly don't
understand them try to explain voice to
a policy person
and and they don't actually like if they
save money they care about them at
budget time but these aren't the ones
that make news because they don't
service residents in the near term right
no resident carers that we migrated the
city's entire email system to Microsoft
365 so why do we care about this
so one when we started this the city
actually didn't have much that was
functioning in the cloud why does that
matter
right so most do you know but the cloud
sounds like a fancy technology term why
do we spend money on that well while it
dropped our email cost down from looking
remember the number it was like from 47
dollars a person to $17 a person or
something like that don't quote me cut
with a while ago but it was that was the
range right we didn't pocket those
savings what we did was actually use
those savings to expand the reach of our
email from the relatively small number
of city employees to all employees which
now means we have actually a
communication network that reaches all
employees which is pretty important that
may actually sound like well doesn't
everybody have email no actually that
wasn't true back in 2014 when we did
this not every city employee had email
which gives you the foundation to do
things like deliver all your pay slips
by email and not on paper I think about
that for a minute
deliver your W choose that way right
city communications all going out over
email that's a big change it also was
our first application that went out to
the cloud so I have to tell you about my
budget hearing where I had all the will
tell me what the cloud is
because whoever named that god help us
right you can't actually sit there say

p.span: it's just somebody else's data set but

div.p: why would you go to the cost in a budget
hearing explain to a bunch of aldermen
what the cloud is
but explaining to them the increased
decreased cost and when you do it for
email which are the technology everyone
understands when you then do it for your
financial applications or your CRM
application or whatever comes next
nobody asks any questions and your data
center gets smaller and your operational
costs go down
you have more money to do the
interesting innovations that people do
care about that do get you press
releases that do actually get you better
engagement with residents so we did
things like okay that cute picture at
the top that looks like a truck with a
bunch of pillars that was us shutting
down a road to build a new data center
and lift the coolers and the compressors
to the roof of the building
so in my five or six years working at
the city I got to shut down the road to
build a data center I will probably
never get to say that again in my life
so that was fun let's go put that one
out there we began migrating and adopted
a strategy around cloud first well
everything that the city does ever be in
the cloud not for a long time not
because we found things that don't
belong in the cloud because we've stuff
that's old and it just isn't ready
so until we upgrade those applications
we can't go to the cloud but we have a
cloud first strategy that stakeholders
actually believe in and don't question
anymore and we began doing migrations
things like ok the VoIP migration what
why does that one matter a 25 year old
centric phone system saved 50 percent on
each phone line the city has 43,000
different phone lines across like all
employees in its entire operation
that's massive savings that brings in
new capabilities to city employees
job so these sustainability projects
never make news I think if something had
gone wrong with building the data center
on the day we shut the road down that
might have made news but knock on wood
that one went well but it frees up money
that the city wouldn't have otherwise
and frees up Headroom for the department
to do innovation project that it
otherwise wouldn't get to do so these
are really important but here I think is
the best thing so those are the three
things that I would call out as sort of
my legacy if I can really use that word
at the time that I was there that data
is now present in every policy
conversation the mayor's office has and
that's a huge change for the city of
about saving paper it was about the fact
that technology can drive and support
process change and that I think will be
the hallmark of major policy
and process initiatives for the city
going forward and then finally the the
recognition in both the budget office in
the mayor's office that sustainability
projects that aren't sexy actually
create room and savings for technology
initiatives that otherwise wouldn't be
funded on their own but here was to me
the most important thing so that's not
the entire team at do it you can't
actually get us all in a picture but we
could get 110 of us that's almost all of
this out at a picnic one day so that's
most of us there was a perception of do
it when I started in in the budget
office in 2011 that the IT department
were but it wasn't a great skill set
that it wasn't particularly innovated
that when I took over as deputy CIO in
the middle of 2012 that I probably was
going to have to get rid of between 1/3
and 2/3 of that department to get
anything good done that's probably
that's a pretty dismal picture right I
think when I took over there were three
people that chose to leave and everybody
else was really really excited about the
opportunities we had ahead of us
partially because we had a new mayor
that got out of our way let us do
whatever we wanted partially because we
had civic partnerships with people like
those of you sitting here and elsewhere
that we're creating pressure around
things like open data that we're
stepping forward to do pro bono work and
use that data to build apps that are
making differences in neighborhoods and
there's nobody in that department that
isn't up to the challenge so when tom
talks about those opportunities those of
you who are thinking about jumping into
government should be excited about those
opportunities it's a great place to work
because of those people who are there
there's nobody who's like anxiously
running out the door at 4 o'clock or
4:30 because they're kind of just
clocking it in and not committed to
their job the skills of that team are
pretty amazing and we were able to get
done all of those things I just talked
about in them
then some because of the people that
were there on the day I started and now
the opinion of the rest of the City

p.span: Department and I think frankly of people

div.p: in the city and Beyond because if you
actually bother to go read the press
etcetera right
Chicago is recognized as a leading smart
city in the US and Beyond we're
recognized as a leading you know
data-driven City if you go and read some
of the press that was all done by the
same team
that nobody wanted to work with and that
everybody thought I was going to have to
fire most of it's all the same people so
they just needed to be tapped into and
excited and allowed to actually do the
work that they wanted to do and listen
to because all of that innovation either
came from those people or through
partnerships that those people were
willing to take on so I think this part
of my job was was working with and
partnering with the folks that I found
there who just wanted a chance to serve
their city through technology and for me
that was the most fulfilling part of the
job so so that's my story that's what I
think we got done in the time that I was
there and very proud of the chance that
I had to serve my city through
technology yes what I got
okay any question in the yet drive to go
from a data informed City to a
data-driven city how do you how do you
see the burgeoning digital divide being
played out there and minimized making
here's a new rhythm of the digital
divide getting worse with the advent of
more advanced technologies right IOT AI
etc I think Chicago has a real
opportunity to lead in addressing that
problem if we take advantage of the the
methods and engagement models that we
learned and pioneered under the be top
grant when we took on the internet
digital divide there are there's some
work afoot to attempt to do that but
we're going to have to get really
serious about it really fast and there's
there some people looking at that
there's a thing out there called the
connection cago challenge radiation
companies investing in that but the
proof will be in the pudding we have an
opportunity there but but we need to see
if it works

and still still does in some areas

we've got a really big contract around

there's contract work in newer areas and

that's relatively homegrown or delivered
through partnerships depending on the

all sorts of things right so training
when we could afford it sort of side by

when we could do that our interest is to

because there's a certain skill sets you
